questions.text: The given image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of Heinz bodies and bite cells suggestive of Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

In Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, after oxidant drug exposure, the peripheral blood smear shows red cells with precipitates of denatured globin which are known as Heinz bodies. 

As the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells similar to the one in this smear are produced.

questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was found dead at home, who had a chronic history of swelling of both limbs and breathlessness. The gross pathological image of his liver is given below. What is the most likely cause of the appearance of the liver?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nutmeg appearance of the liver, seen in heart failure.

Congestive hepatopathy, also known as chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion; it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure. It can also occur due to isolated venous obstruction.

Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as a nutmeg liver. Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This appearance occurs due to hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes,  dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of parotid glands and dryness of buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. All are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal and salivary glands are mainly involved

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing solid food, and the findings such as enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibodies positive for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren's syndrome.  The histopathology shows the focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the minor salivary gland. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can manifest as primary or secondary. Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50-60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens- SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. 

Patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A young man presented with hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules. He has a past history of hepatitis B infection. Vasculitis was suspected and a biopsy of the vessel was done. The histopathology of the tissue from the vessel is shown below. Identify the type of necrosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa and the above image depicts fibrinoid necrosis. It is seen in vasculitis like polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in which the small and medium-sized blood vessels are affected as a result of immune complex deposition.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection, which causes the HBsAg-HbsAb complexes to deposit in affected vessels. Clinical manifestations are a result of ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues that are affected.

The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels in which the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessel walls. These complexes elicit an immune reaction leading to cell injury and leakage of fibrin and plasma proteins around the blood vessel and giving a circumferential pinkish appearance of necrosis. 

It is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality if left untreated.

The image below shows fibrinoid necrosis with intraluminal thrombosis in an artery of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa. 

Necrosis refers to irreversible cell death caused by the denaturation of proteins and enzymatic digestion of the injured cells. 

Gangrenous necrosis commonly occurs in the lower limbs due to decreased blood supply. This type of necrosis is usually coagulative necrosis and is called dry gangrene.

When this becomes superimposed with bacterial infection the harmful enzymes from the bacteria and inflammatory cells result in liquefactive necrosis which is called wet gangrene.

Caseous necrosis (cheese like) refers to a friable yellow white area of necrosis as seen in this image

  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic focus appears as a collection of fragmented or lysed cells with an amorphous granular pink appearance surrounded by inflammatory cells called as granuloma and is classical of tuberculosis as shown below.

Fat necrosis refers to the localised destruction of fat by pancreatic enzymes. The commonest cause of this type of necrosis is acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, these enzymes are released within or around the pancreas breaking down the triglycerides into fatty acids. When calcium binds to fatty acid it results in fat saponification giving a chalky white appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. Histology shows characteristic fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with intraluminal thrombosis. This condition is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality.

questions.text: Histopathology of a patient who had pulmonary edema shows the following. The cells seen within the alveolar spaces are:
questions.solution:
• Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
  • In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces, where they are phagocytosed and digested by macrophages, which store the iron recovered from hemoglobin in the form of hemosiderin.
  • These hemosiderin-laden macrophages (also known as heart failure cells) are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Identify the condition where the cells marked in the image is seen:
questions.solution:
The slide shows Anitschkow cells or caterpillar cells which are pathognomic for RF.

  • During acute rheumatic fever, focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues.
  • Distinctive lesions in the heart - Aschoff bodies, consisting of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF)
  • These Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”)

 

Histology showing Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells in Rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. 

Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: 10 year old child presents with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Lymph node biopsy was performed, which shows cells as in the given figure. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Hodgkin lymphoma; EBV and embryo cell
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma; HIV and giant B cell
Hodgkin lymphoma; EBV and Reed Sternberg cell

questions.solution: The sine qua non (an essential condition) of Hodgkin lymphoma is the Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, a very large cell (15 to 45 μm in diameter) with an enormous multilobate nucleus, exceptionally prominent nucleoli, and abundant, usually slightly eosinophilic, cytoplasm. Particularly characteristic are cells with two mirror image nuclei or nuclear lobes, each containing a large (inclusion-like) acidophilic nucleolus surrounded by a clear zone, features that impart an owl-eye appearance.

questions.text: The appearance of fibers in the histological image below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rosenthal fibers, which are commonly associated with pilocytic astrocytoma.

A Rosenthal fiber is a thick, elongated, worm-like, or "corkscrew" eosinophilic bundle that is found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long-standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders. It is usually associated with pilocytic astrocytoma (more common) or Alexander's disease (a rare leukodystrophy).

Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma or juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma or cystic cerebellar astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults (in the first 20 years of life).
  • These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The neoplasms are associated with the formation of a single (or multiple) cyst(s) and can become very large.
  • Diagnosis can be made on the basis of brain MRI findings. Surgery is usually the treatment of choice. Total resection is often possible.

questions.text:
A patient presented with severe fatigue and a history of recurrent infections. Abdominal examination showed no features of organomegaly. His CBC showed pancytopenia and bone marrow aspirate gave a dry tap. Marrow biopsy shows a markedly hypocellular bone marrow. What is the likely diagnosis?

CBC - complete blood count
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with pancytopenia, dry tap on bone marrow aspiration, and marrow biopsy showing markedly hypocellular bone marrow are suggestive of aplastic anemia.

Aplastic anemia is a chronic primary hematological failure that results in pancytopenia. Causes of this condition include:

  • Idiopathic 
  • Idiosyncratic reactions to drugs such as chloramphenicol
  • Infections such as viral hepatitis
  • Inherited defects such as Fanconi anemia or inherited telomerase defects.

The pathology is thought to be due to damaged stem cells producing progeny that express neoantigens which cause an autoimmune reaction or due to the production of a clonal population with decreased proliferating capacity.

Clinically, the patients present with features of pancytopenia such as fatigue, recurrent infections, and petechiae and ecchymoses. Characteristically, splenomegaly will be absent.

A peripheral smear will show reticulocytopenia. Bone marrow aspirates often give a 'dry tap' which means that they yield little material. Thus, a marrow biopsy would show a markedly hypocellular marrow that is devoid of hematopoietic cells (some fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes or plasma cells remain).

Other options:

Option A: Megaloblastic anemia is caused by folate or vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia). Peripheral smear shows characteristic macro-ovalocytic red cells that appear hyperchromic, hypersegmented nuclei in neutrophils, and reticulocytopenia. Marrow is markedly hypercellular due to an increase in the number of hematopoietic precursors.

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. Peripheral smears show microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. Bone marrow shows an increase in erythroid progenitors. A significant diagnostic finding is an absence of stainable iron in macrophages which is assessed by Prussian blue stain on aspirated marrow smears.

Option D: Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a primary marrow disorder that causes the suppression of erythroid progenitors only. One cause is acute parvovirus B19 infection which may lead to an aplastic crisis in patients who already had underlying hemolytic anemia. The hallmark of PRCA, in an otherwise normal marrow, is the absence of erythroblasts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of seizures. Imaging revealed the presence of a tumor in the frontal lobe. Surgery was done, and the biopsy specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a frontal lobe tumor, presenting with seizures and the histopathology image showing the ‘fried egg appearance’ of tumor cells, points to the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is a subtype of infiltrating glioma. It is comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives it the ‘fried egg appearance.’ The tumor cells that infiltrate the cortex usually collect around the neuron, and this is known as perineural satellitosis. There is a delicate network of anastomosing thin-walled capillaries between the tumor cells, resembling 'chicken wire.'

Oligodendrogliomas are most commonly detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes. It is treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Glioblastoma is a synonym for grade IV astrocytoma. Infiltrating astrocytomas and glioblastomas are usually seen in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Histologically, glioblastoma appears like an anaplastic astrocytoma with serpiginous foci of palisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation. 

Option C: Ependymomas in adults occur in the spinal cord and near the ventricles, particularly the fourth ventricle. The microscopic appearance shows both true rosettes and perivascular pseudorosettes.

Option D: Schwannomas are benign tumors often arising directly from peripheral nerves. On microscopy, they are comprised of dense areas called Antoni A areas and loose areas referred to as Antoni B areas. Antoni A areas are eosinophilic and contain spindle cells arranged in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading. The central nuclear-free zones are called Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are a component of NF-2.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Biopsy of the tumor from spinal cord in the patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ependymomas most often arise next to the ependyma lined ventricular system, including the central canal of the spinal cord.
  • In the first 2 decades of life, they typically occur near the fourth ventricle and constitute 5% to 10% of the primary brain tumors in this age group.
  • In adults, the spinal cord is their most common location; tumors in this site are particularly frequent in the setting of neurofibromatosis type 2
  • Microscopically, the tumors are composed of cells with regular, round to oval nuclei and abundant granular chromatin. Between the nuclei is a variably dense fibrillary background.
  • Tumor cells may form round or elongated structures (rosettes, canals) that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into a lumen, more frequently present are perivascular pseudorosettes in which tumor cells are arranged around vessels with an intervening zone containing thin ependymal processes

questions.text: An older patient with bilateral hearing loss and occasional vertigo is being investigated. Biopsy from the region is given below. The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The given histology image shows dense pink Antoni A areas predominantly (bottom left) and loose, pale Antoni B areas (top right), as well as hyalinized blood vessels seen in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves. They are associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 (Neurofibromatosis 2) gene on chromosome 22.

They appear as well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached loosely to the associated nerve without invading. They cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures.

Their cell of origin is the Schwann cell, thus they show immunoreactivity for the S-100 marker.

Treatment is done using surgical removal.

Other options:

Option A: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors, that often arise in the uterus and are the most common neoplasm in women. Histologically, they are composed of fascicles of densely eosinophilic spindle cells that tend to intersect each other at right angles. 

Option B: Rhabdomyomas are the most frequent primary tumors of the heart in children. Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. But due to routine histological processing, the glycogen content is reduced and looks like thin strands that stretch from the nuclei to the surface membrane, which appears like ‘spider cells’.

Option D: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors and the histological picture shows the presence of bland Schwann cells admixed with stromal cells such as mast cells, perineural cells, and fibroblasts. The stroma of the tumors contains loose collagen arranged in wavy bundles.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

questions.text:
A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show the following findings. The blasts are positive for CD33. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 8.5 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000/Cumm

TLC: 52,000/Cumm with 83% blasts
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. 

The peripheral smear shows blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, Auer rods, and delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli. The blasts are positive for CD33. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients.

 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.

The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³.

It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen.

  • Total blood count:
    • Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. 
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections.
    • 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells.
  • Peripheral smear:
    • Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
    • Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears.
    • Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.
    • Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both)
  • Lymph node biopsy:
    • Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates
    • Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL.

The chromosomal defects:

  • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
  • Deletion of 11q
  • Trisomy 12q
  • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anaemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true about this patient’s condition?

choices.text: All forms of this tumour are associated with translocations of the MYC gene
Endemic  forms are latently infected with EBV
Tumor exhibits a high mitotic index
Neoplastic cells are usually BCL2 positive

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Neoplastic cells in Burkitt's lymphoma are usually BCL2 negative.

The biopsy image shows the classical finding of Burkitt's lymphoma called the starry sky appearance.

Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky).

The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars).

Burkitt lymphoma is the most common NHL in children <15 years.

Three distinct clinical forms of Burkitt's lymphoma are:

  • Endemic- affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla, and is EBV-associated.
  • Sporadic- in adults in western countries.
  • Immunodeficiency associated- is associated with HIV infection.

It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67). Histology shows the characteristic starry sky pattern.

Immunophenotypic markers include:

  • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
  • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
  • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
  • HLA-DR and CD43
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors
    • Endemic BL: EBV (+), express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL: EBV (--) and lack CD21 expression

Treatment must begin within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium for 6 months. His hemogram and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 10 gm/dL

TLC - 5.5 lakhs/mm3

Platelet count - 4 lakhs/mm3
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). 

In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. 

The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.

Clinical features of CML:

  • Hypermetabolism
  • Fatigability
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss and anorexia
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
    • Splenomegaly
    • Mild hepatomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy

Hematological findings include:

  • Mild-to-moderate anemia 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Platelets - usually increased
  • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%) 

Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in CLL.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman complains about throbbing pain over both palms. Her examination findings and lab reports are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 11 g/dL

WBC - 9,000 /mm3

Platelet count - 7,00,000 /μL

Bone marrow biopsy - hypercellular with megakaryocytes and reticulin fibrils

Philadelphia chromosome - absent

MPL mutation - positive
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The image showing erythematous hands is suggestive of erythromelalgia.

Essential thrombocythemia (essential thrombocytosis) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is associated with mutations that increase JAK-STAT signaling.

WHO criteria for diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia:

  • Major criteria -
    • Platelet count ≥450 × 109/L
    • Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation mainly of the megakaryocyte lineage with increased numbers of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei
    • Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 chronic myeloid leukemia, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms
    • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation
  • Minor criteria - the presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive thrombocytosis

Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor criterion

Option A: Polycythemia vera can also present with erythromelalgia. However, it also presents with increased Hb levels. 

Option C: Fibrosis (not reticulin fibrils) is seen in bone marrow biopsy of primary myelofibrosis. 

Option D: WBC counts are increased in leukemoid reactions.

questions.text: The cross-section of the brain of an 84-year-old man with dyslipidemia is given below, in comparison with a normal brain. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change?
questions.solution:
The given image shows narrowing of gyri and widening of sulci in a senile brain, which is suggestive of senile atrophy. It is due to a gradual decrease in blood supply as a result of atherosclerosis, known as ischemic atrophy.

The various types of pathological atrophy are:

Pathologic atrophy 
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was admitted with sudden, substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm. On examination, he was diaphoretic and dyspneic with an irregular pulse. Despite resuscitative measures, he died within an hour of admission. Autopsy revealed the following gross appearance of the interventricular myocardium. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing dead tissue are suggestive of myocardial infarction. It is characterized by coagulative necrosis.

In coagulative necrosis, despite cell death, the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved for a few days. This is because the cell injury is mainly due to the denaturation of all proteins, including the enzymatic proteins. This prevents the proteolysis of the dead cells. Ultimately, these necrotized cells are removed by phagocytosis and the lysosomal action of the enzymes of the leukocytes.

Examples of coagulative necrosis:

  • Ischemic injury in all organs, except the brain
  • Dry gangrene

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen.

An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ infarts is thromboembolism.

The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due to alcoholism.

The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on hematoxylin and eosin staining.

A few causes of fatty liver are as follows:

  • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity
  • Toxins
  • Malnutrition
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Anoxia

Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys.

The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids.

questions.text: An elderly man diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung underwent surgical resection. Histopathological examination of the resected hilar lymph nodes revealed the following finding as given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological image of the lymph node showing abundant black-colored pigment within the macrophages are characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis.

The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes, which causes the blackening of the tissues. The carbon dust may also induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with carbon particles, such as coal mines. 

The following images show the accumulation of various types of pigments within cells.

The 4th of May is observed as Coal Miner's day.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as follows.  Which of the following does this represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside. 

Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: A 45 -year-old HIV-positive patient has patchy pneumonia.  Smears of induced sputum and sedimented cells from lavage fluid stained with methenamine silver are as seen below. Which is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The smears stained with methenamine silver show black-colored stained cysts resembling the crushed ping pong balls of Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Approximately 15% to 30% of untreated HIV-infected people develop pneumonia during the course of the disease. It is mainly caused by the fungus P. jirovecii (reactivation of prior latent infection).

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition except ______.

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen
Portal fibrosis and proliferation of portal bile ducts

questions.solution:
Clinical history and gross image suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are associated with cysts in liver, spleen, and pancreas; berry aneurysms; and mitral valve prolapse.

Note: 

Patients with autosomal-recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Cysts in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis à subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1 and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney

questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to OPD with complaints of blood in his urine. Examination reveals a non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline. Blood pressure is also found to be elevated. Imaging reveals a left renal tumor and surgical resection is planned. The gross appearance of the mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing a well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes in the upper pole of the kidney are suggestive of a nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumor. 

It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 years of age). Around 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes and gonadal dysgenesis may be seen. 

Clinical manifestations of Wilms' tumor include:

  • Large abdominal mass - usually unilateral and does not cross the midline
  • Abdominal pain
  • Hematuria
  • Hypertension
  • Intestinal obstruction (in some cases) 

Nephrogenic rests are the precursor lesions of Wilms' tumor and suggest an increased risk of developing a contralateral Wilms' tumor.

questions.text: Seen below is the microscopic appearance of a liver biopsy section. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
The above slide is of hereditary hemochromatosis which is an autosomal recessive condition.

The liver biopsy section stained with Perl's Prussian Blue shows blue stained hepatocyte iron accumulation.

Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

  • When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis.
  • When accumulation occurs as a consequence of parenteral administration of iron- secondary hemochromatosis.
  • Total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults; about 0.5 gm is stored in the liver, 98% of which is in hepatocytes.
  • The following features characterize severe iron overload in the body:
    • Micronodular cirrhosis
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Abnormal skin pigmentation
  • Iron accumulation in hereditary forms is lifelong but the injury caused by excessive iron is slow and progressive; hence symptoms usually first appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life in men and later in women
  • In hereditary hemochromatosis, regulation of intestinal absorption of dietary iron is abnormal, leading to net iron accumulation of 0.5 to 1 gm/year.
  • The main regulator of iron absorption is the protein hepcidin, encoded by the HAMP gene and secreted by the liver
  • Other proteins involved in iron metabolism, do so by regulating hepcidin levels. These include
    • Hemojuvelin (HJV)
    • Transferrin receptor 2 (TFR2)
    • HFE, the product of the hemochromatosis gene.
  • Decreased hepcidin synthesis has a central role in the pathogenesis of hemochromatosis.
  • The adult form of hemochromatosis is almost always caused by mutations of HFE; mutation of TFR2 is far less common.
  • Mutations in HAMP and HJV cause severe juvenile hemochromatosis
  • Manifestations
    • Deposition of hemosiderin in the following organs (in decreasing order of severity) the liver, pancreas, myocardium, pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid and parathyroid glands, joints, and skin;
    • Cirrhosis; and
    • Pancreatic fibrosis.
  • Liver -Golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes that stain with Prussian blue small, shrunken liver with a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis.
  • Biochemical determination of hepatic tissue iron concentration has been the gold standard for quantitating hepatic iron
  • The therapy of hemochromatosis involves removal of the excess body iron, best accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL (200–250 mg of iron).
  • Chelating agents such as desferoxamine, when given parenterally, remove 10–20 mg of iron per day, which is much less than that
    mobilized by once-weekly phlebotomy.
  • Death may result from cirrhosis or cardiac disease.
  • A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinomas.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the most common form of thyroid carcinoma
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes are more commonly associated with this condition.

It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with a soap bubble appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone.

GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.

GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue.

Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma.

Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally.

Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT.

 Note: The E mnemonic for GCT:

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: An obese 35-year-old man with renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain in the right knee. It is associated with localized hyperemia. Joint aspiration is done which shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and the following finding under polarised light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals that are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent. 

Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate (MSU) within and around joints. This results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes. Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines.

The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are acute arthritis, chronic tophaceous arthritis, tophi in various sites, and gouty nephropathy. Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout. These are large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, bursae, earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys.

Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a pearly papule over the face containing prominent dilated subepidermal blood vessels and surface ulceration. A histological picture of the tumor is shown below. All are true about the tumor except:

choices.text: Incidence is increased in xeroderma pigmentosum

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and histology are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). It is a locally aggressive cutaneous tumor, and metastasis is very rare.

It occurs in sun-exposed areas with increased incidence in the setting of immunosuppression and in disorders of DNA repair, such as xeroderma pigmentosum.

BCCs usually present as pearly papules and locally invasive ulcers (rodent ulcers). Histologically, the tumor cells resemble those in the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis with peripheral palisading and retraction cleft.

It is associated with mutations that activate the hedgehog pathway signaling.

Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder with multiple basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms, and soles.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with oral ulcers and bullae over the mucosa and skin. On examination, the bullae are flaccid and filled with clear fluid. Histopathology of the lesion shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the suprabasal splitting of the epidermis (acantholysis) giving rise to the row of tombstones appearance. This is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. It involves the mucosa and skin. Autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present.

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

Variants of pemphigus:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Pemphigus vegetans
  • Pemphigus foliaceus - autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.
  • Pemphigus erythematosus
  • Paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.

On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.

Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.

A 40 year old male presents with complaints of bleeding gums for the past 2 weeks. He has thickened and friable gums with hepatosplenomegaly with generalized non-tender lymphadenopathy. The blood count reveals: Hb - 10g/dl 
Platelet count 80,000/mm3

The peripheral smear is as seen below  
The bone marrow aspiration and biopsy shows many large blasts that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive. What of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, morphology and cytochemistry are suggestive of acute monocytic leukemia.

Subtypes

  • 80%+ of monocyte lineage cells are monoblasts – Acute monoblastic leukemia
  • <80% of monocyte lineage cells are monoblasts, usually < 20%) – Acute monocytic leukemia 

Acute monocytic leukemia

  • High incidence of bleeding disorders (including DIC), organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, CNS and other tissue involvement (monocytes infiltrate)
  • Greater than 20% blasts in the bone marrow, and of these, greater than 80% must be of the monocytic lineage.
  • Monoblasts can be distinguished by having a roughly circular nucleus, delicate lacy chromatin, and abundant, often basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Monoblasts are typically MPO-negative and promonocytes are MPO variable.
  • Both monoblasts and promonocytes stain positive for non-specific esterase(NSE).
